request_pathways.name: Authorization to Release Protected Health Information
Secure email submission of authorization form

forms.document_type: Incoming records request form (authorization for other facilities to send records TO Ironwood)
ROI authorization form (outbound release of patient PHI)
New patient forms packet with HIPAA contact list

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient must download a generic authorization-to-release form (not linked from the website), print and handwrite it, then submit via fax, secure email, mail, or in person.

red_flags: Patient-facing ROI form has zero fillable fields while the provider-facing incoming records form has 22 fillable fields
ROI form is not linked from any active webpage — only discoverable via search engines
Wrong state law citation (Washington RCW 70.24) on form-1 despite being an Arizona practice
bright_spots: "Personal Use" listed as first purpose option, explicitly acknowledging patient self-access
Five delivery methods including secure email and patient portal — better than most comparable practices

findability.rationale: Level 2: The form is not linked from the patient forms page and was only discoverable via site-specific search engine queries; the patient forms page at ironwoodcrc.com/patient-forms/ did not expose downloadable links.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: The form has a text layer but zero fillable fields requiring print-and-handwrite; however, fax and secure email submission options make it usable digitally with workarounds.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Logically organized with clear record-type checkboxes and delivery options, but lacks any instructions or plain-language guidance, and the To/From field layout is confusing for patient self-access.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the generic authorization form but it wasn't designed for them; the To/From structure assumes third-party release, though 'Personal Use' as a purpose option partially accommodates self-access.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Vague fee disclosure ('A fee may be charged') without distinguishing patient access fees from third-party fees goes beyond what HIPAA requires; no Right of Access reference, though non-conditioning and revocation rights are properly stated.

overall.summary: Ironwood provides a minimally adequate but deprioritized patient access pathway through a generic, non-fillable authorization form that is not linked from the website, partially redeemed by multiple electronic delivery options.
